items.standfirst: For today’s news updates as they happen in Brisbane and beyond, follow us here.
items.content: For today’s news updates as they happen in Brisbane and beyond, follow us here.

items.title: Man with murder of woman whose body was found in Brisbane River
items.standfirst: C rystal Beale, 49, had left a family dinner one night in February and took a ride with her her killer, police now allege.
items.content: A man has been charged with murder over the death of Crystal Beale, whose body was found in a river earlier this year in Brisbane. A member of the public saw Beale's body in the Brisbane River at about 5.40am on Saturday, February 22, and contacted police.Investigators believe that at 8.30pm on Friday, February 1, Beale, 49, left a family dinner at a Sunnybank restaurant and travelled with a 49-year-old West End man, who was known to her.READ MORE: MAGA firebrand laughs on stage at Charlie Kirk memorialHe was allegedly the last person to see Beale alive when she got out of the car at 9.30pm on Ryan Street, West End.But police now allege the man killed Beale and put her body into the Brisbane River. Police searched an Equestrian Drive address in Maudsland at 5.11am this morning.A 49-year-old man was arrested and charged with domestic violence murder and misconduct with a corpse.He is expected to appear in court today.Support is available from the National Sexual Assault, Domestic and Family Violence Counselling Service at 1800RESPECT (1800 737 732).

items.title: Police arrest man over murder of Crystal Beale
items.standfirst: Police have arrested and charged a West End man with the murder of Crystal Beale and of dumping her body in the Brisbane River.
items.content: Police have arrested and charged a West End man with the murder of Crystal Beale and of dumping her body in the Brisbane River.

items.standfirst: Ms Beale's body was found in the Brisbane River by a member of the public in the early hours of February 22.

clusters.title: Albanese says he’d be surprised if Optus boss wasn’t considering his future
clusters.neutral_headline: Optus Faces Scrutiny After Triple Zero Outage
bullet_summary: T he telco giant's outage that blocked hundreds of Triple Zero calls is an "enormous failure", Anika Wells said
Reported by The Age, 9News, ABC Just In

items.title: Albanese says he’d be surprised if Optus boss wasn’t considering his future
items.standfirst: The prime minister says Optus hasn’t fulfilled its Triple Zero obligations, while Communications Minister Anika Wells says the telco “perpetuated an enormous failure on the Australian people”.
items.content: The prime minister says Optus hasn’t fulfilled its Triple Zero obligations, while Communications Minister Anika Wells says the telco “perpetuated an enormous failure on the Australian people”.

items.title: Optus to face 'consequences', minister promises after outage
items.standfirst: T he telco giant's outage that blocked hundreds of Triple Zero calls is an "enormous failure", Anika Wells said.
items.content: Optus can expect "consequences" after another outage left people unable to contact Triple Zero in an "enormous failure", Communications Minister Anika Wells said.Multiple people died during the network outage, during which they were unable to reach emergency services. Following Optus chief executive Stephen Rue's admission yesterday that the telco had missed several warnings that calls to Triple Zero were not going through, Wells this morning confirmed Optus had been told about the issue but not acted on it.READ MORE: Jewish leaders in Australia blast recognition of Palestinian statehood "Optus will be held to account," she said."Optus and all telecommunications providers have obligations under Australian law to make sure emergency services calls go through."Wells and Australian Communications and Media Authorit y head Nerida O'Loughlin did not specify what consequences Optus would face, but O'Loughlin noted that the telco had been penalised $12 million after breaching similar laws in 2023. O'Loughlin said 624 Triple Zero calls had been affected during the outage, which occurred between 12.30am and 1.30pm on Thursday in South Australia, Western Australia, and the Northern Territory.She said initial emails from Optus about the scale of the outage had been "perfunctory" and "inaccurate".Under existing regulations, telecommunications companies are required to tell stakeholders, including the government and ACMA, as soon as an outage is detected. READ MORE: Man dead after being hit by forklift at warehouse "In this case we weren't notified at all until the outage was resolved," O'Loughlin said.ACMA is undertaking a thorough investigation of the incident, though Wells and O'Loughlin did not say when they expected that to be resolved."Once we have the facts about what has happened and once I take the recommendations that come from the recommendation from ACMA, I will then consider what is an appropriate response for the telecommunications as a whole," Wells said. The minister also indicated that the outage could prompt a broader examination of the industry, noting that Optus was not the only provider to have overseen Triple Zero outages."This is not entirely a matter for Optus," Wells said."We are considering what needs to be done holistically or as part of legislative relief for the Australian people, given their confidence has no doubt been shaken by what has happened here. "DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

items.title: Optus will be 'held accountable' over triple-0 failure, minister says
items.standfirst: The Australian Media and Communications Authority has begun its investigation into an Optus triple-0 outage that has been linked to multiple deaths in South Australia and Western Australia.
items.content: The Australian Media and Communications Authority has begun its investigation into an Optus triple-0 outage that has been linked to multiple deaths in South Australia and Western Australia.

items.title: Optus outage 'unlikely' to have contributed to eight-week-old baby's death
items.standfirst: A critical outage in the telco giant's network meant Triple Zero calls in South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were blocked
items.content: An initial investigation has revealed the death of an eight-week-old baby on Thursday was unlikely to have been contributed to by a triple zero outage on the Optus network.A critical outage in the telco giant's network meant triple zero calls in South Australia, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were blocked, with the company announcing it had contributed to three deaths; a fourth was later confirmed by WA Premier Roger Cook.One of the initial deaths announced by Optus was that of an eight-month-old baby boy in Gawler, north of Adelaide.Opinion: Optus has many questions to answer after another staggering failureThe boy's grandmother had initially told police she had tried to call triple zero on her mobile phone after realising her grandson was not breathing.However, a statement from South Australia Police today has shed more light on the incident, revealing it was likely not a factor behind the infant's tragic death."While the family was impacted by the Optus outage, it appears at this stage it is unlikely to have contributed to the death," the statement said."When her call was not connected, she immediately used another mobile telephone in the house and was successfully connected to triple zero.READ MORE: 'I'm absolutely disgusted': South Australian man couldn't call for ambulance during Optus outage"The preliminary investigations indicate the child's death is not due to any delay in SAAS [emergency services] attending the Mulga St house, despite the failure of the first attempt to call 000."SA Police said it did not usually make public comments such as this, but believed the public interest in the story meant transparency was required.They confirmed a full investigation was being provided to the coroner, who will decide whether an inquest will be required.Police also said the investigation into other death in the state connected to the outage, a 68-year-old woman from Queenstown, was still ongoing.Optus chief executive Stephen Rue is scheduled to address the media at 3pm AEST today.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.

ai_summary: Optus will face "consequences" following a major outage.
The outage blocked hundreds of Triple Zero calls.
The Australian Media and Communications Authority is investigating the outage.
The outage has been linked to multiple deaths in South Australia and Western Australia.
The prime minister said Optus has not fulfilled its Triple Zero obligations.

clusters.title: Aged care worker to front court over allegedly defrauding elderly residents
clusters.neutral_headline: Aged Care Worker Charged with Defrauding Residents

items.title: Aged care worker to front court over allegedly defrauding elderly residents
items.standfirst: T he 23-year-old woman has been charged with more than 100 offences.
items.content: A n aged care worker in south-east Queensland has been charged with 113 offences over allegedly defrauding elderly people in her care.The 23-year-old woman allegedly obtained bank details from four elderly victims at an aged care centre in Rothwell, south of Brisbane, where she worked and used them to make personal purchases between last October and June.She has been charged with 110 counts of fraud and one count each of enter dwelling with intent, enter dwelling and obtaining identification information.READ MORE: Staggering number of Aussie jobs at risk over AIShe is due to appear before Redcliffe Magistrates Court on Wednesday.Police say officers carried out an extensive investigation that examined a web of online and in-person purchases. "I thank the victims and their loved ones for reporting suspicious banking activity and purchases," Detective Senior Sergeant Elkins said."Taking advantage of the elderly members in our community will not be tolerated."The Queensland Government has an Elder Abuse Helpline and free seniors legal services which can offer support to elderly people.If you or someone you know has been a victim of a similar offence, please contact police.DOWNLOAD THE 9NEWS APP: Stay across all the latest in breaking news, sport, politics and the weather via our news app and get notifications sent straight to your smartphone. Available on the Apple App Store and Google Play.
